conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves backward above the objects.
The image shows objects on a wooden floor with their corresponding shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
The objects include a cake (shadow A), a sandal/shoe (shadow B), an unidentified dark object (shadow C), and a domino or game piece (shadow D).
Each object casts a shadow on the wooden floor, with the shadows labeled with red arrows.
When a light source moves backward, shadows move closer to directly beneath their objects, become smaller, and become sharper (less diffuse).
Shadow A (from the cake) will move closer to being directly under the cake and become smaller as the light source moves backward.
Shadow B (from the sandal/shoe) will move closer to being directly under the object and become smaller as the light source moves backward.
Shadow C (from the dark object at the bottom left) will move closer to being directly under its source and become smaller as the light source moves backward.
Shadow D (from the domino or game piece) will move closer to being directly under its source and become smaller as the light source moves backward.
The second image shows all shadows moving closer to being directly beneath their respective objects, appearing smaller in size, and more defined/sharper.
When the light source moves backward, shadows A, B, C, and D all move closer to being directly beneath their respective objects, become smaller in size, and become more defined/sharper.
The overall effect is that the shadows 'contract' toward the objects that cast them.
